summary: Lymphoma is a group of blood and lymph tumors that develop from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. It is a broad category encompassing many subtypes, with the two main classifications being non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) and Hodgkin lymphoma (HL). Lymphomas are part of the broader group of tumors of hematopoietic and lymphoid tissues.
causes: Epstein–Barr virus infection (risk factor for Hodgkin lymphoma)
Human T-lymphotropic virus infection (risk factor for non-Hodgkin lymphomas)
Autoimmune diseases (risk factor for non-Hodgkin lymphomas)
Immunosuppressant medications (risk factor for non-Hodgkin lymphomas)
Epstein-Barr virus (responsible for development/progression of EBV-associated lymphoproliferative diseases)
risk_factors: Family history of the disease (Hodgkin lymphoma)
Eating large amounts of red meat (may increase risk)
Weakened immune system (from HIV infection, certain drugs or medication)
Male sex (implicit in some epidemiological data)
symptoms: B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss)
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., ABVD regimen, BEACOPP, CHOP, R-CHOP)
Targeted therapy (e.g., rituximab, chimeric antigen receptor T cell therapies)
Plasmapheresis (for non-Hodgkin lymphomas with protein buildup)
Bone marrow or stem cell transplant (including autologous stem cell transplantation)
Physical exercises (for adult patients with hematological malignancies)
subtypes: Large B cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
Diffuse large B cell lymphoma associated with chronic inflammation
Fibrin-associated diffuse large B cell lymphoma
Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma, nasal type
Peripheral T cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
Systemic T cell lymphoma of childhood
